Authors:
Vladimir Mikryukov, Elena N. Bilanenko, Natalya I
Bondarenko, Denis V Goryunov, Vladimir E Fedosov, Maria D Logacheva,
Kirill V. Mikhailov, Irina Milyutina, Alexaned P Mylnikov, Leonid Rusin,
Sergey A Spirin, Vladimir V. Aleoshin
Title:
Unexpected diversity of early diverging Holomycota in fungal
communities of a boreal peatland
Keywords:
Fungi; Holomycota; Microsporidia; Oxygen deficiency;
Peatland
Abstract:
Northern peatlands hold vast reserves of organic-rich soil
and are characterized by harsh environmental conditions, such as high
acidity, low temperatures, and oxygen deficiency, creating unique
ecological niches for extremotolerant species. Eukaryotic communities
from deep horizons of boreal peatlands potentially contain large
diversity of fungal species that are poorly accessible to
non-sequence-based detection methods. In this work, we describe
Holomycota communities associated with organic matter and pore water in
oxygen-depleted horizons of a boreal peatland in the Moscow region using
high-throughput sequencing of highly variable domains of the 18S rRNA
gene. We find high abundance and diversity of zoosporic fungi and taxa
with a yeast-like growth, indicating the similarity of deep peat
communities with aquatic ones. Many Eumycota taxa in the peatland are
found to be represented by extremotolerant fungi, including dwellers of
extreme habitats  Neocallimastigomycota and Wallemiomycetes. Remarkably,
sequences belonging to the early-diverging Holomycota phylum
Rozellomycota (Cryptomycota) appear to dominate peat and water
communities, accounting for 2580% of the Holomycota sequences. With only
a few exceptions, the deep peat was found to contain representatives
from all major clades of the Rozellomycota phylum. Our results expand
the diversity of fungal lineages and show that deep oxygen-depleted
horizons of boreal peatland serve as repositories of early-diverging
Holomycota species.
